name: Jools Holland
description:
'''Julian Miles Holland''' {{post-nominals|country=GBR|OBE|DL}} (born 24 January 1958) is an English pianist, bandleader, singer, composer and television presenter. He was an original member of the rock band [[Squeeze (band)|Squeeze]]. From 1982 until 1987, he co-presented the [[Channel 4]] music programme ''[[The Tube (1982 TV series)|The Tube]]''. Since 1992, he has hosted ''[[Later... with Jools Holland]]'', a music show aired on [[BBC2]], on which his annual show ''[[Jools' Annual Hootenanny|Hootenanny]]'' is based. Holland is a published author and appears on television shows besides his own. He regularly hosted the programme ''Jools Holland'' on [[BBC Radio 2]].

In 2004, Holland collaborated with the Welsh singer [[Tom Jones (singer)|Tom Jones]] on an album of traditional [[Rhythm and blues|R&B]] music. He achieved his first UK number one album in 2024 with ''[[Swing Fever (album)|Swing Fever]]'', a collaboration with [[Rod Stewart]]. He has worked with many other artists including [[Marc Almond]], [[Jayne County]], [[Jos√© Feliciano]], [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], [[Eric Clapton]], [[Mark Knopfler]], [[George Harrison]], [[David Gilmour]], [[Ringo Starr]], [[Dr. John]], [[Bono]], [[The The]], [[Ruby Turner]], and [[Amy Winehouse]].
